con.para: Forces are pushes or pulls that can change the motion of an object. They are responsible for everything from how we walk to how planets orbit around the Sun.
Forces can be divided into two main categories: *contact forces* and *non-contact forces.*
Contact forces occur when objects physically touch each other. A *push* or *pull* is a basic example of a contact force—think of pushing a door open or pulling a rope.
*Friction* is another contact force, which happens when two surfaces rub against each other, like when your shoes grip the ground to prevent slipping.
Tension, on the other hand, occurs in objects like ropes or strings when they are pulled tight, such as when you tug on a rope during a game of tug-of-war.
Non-contact forces work even when objects are not touching. *Gravity* is a perfect example—it pulls objects toward the Earth, like when you drop something and it falls to the ground.
*Magnetic* forces are also non-contact forces. They can pull or push objects without physically touching them, like when a magnet attracts metal.

Finally, *electric forces* can attract or repel objects that carry an electric charge, even from a distance. These invisible forces have a significant impact on our everyday lives, even though we can’t always see them.
